column13: Developed a cross-functional climate change scenario analysis working group to deliver insights on climate-related risks and opportunities for the Group. Updated the governance framework to support delivering and integrating climate scenario analysis insights. Developed considerations for integrating climate risks and opportunities into business planning cycles.
column20: Cross-Functional Climate Change, Governance Framework, Climate Risks and Opportunities

column13: Continue to engage closely with state government agencies on initiatives, including the Queensland GovernmentÃ¢ÂÂs Resilient Homes Fund and the NSW GovernmentÃ¢ÂÂs Northern Rivers Reconstruction Corporation. Contributed to the Insurance Council of AustraliaÃ¢ÂÂs Climate Change Action Committee and the Net-Zero Working Group, including the industry response to the Federal TreasuryÃ¢ÂÂs mandatory climate-related disclosure consultation.

column13: Over the past few years, weÃ¢ÂÂve focused intensely on our fleet, reducing energy consumption and sourcing renewable energy for our offices. In the last three years, weÃ¢ÂÂve reduced our office space by 19% by consolidating our Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne workplaces, and 77% of the electricity we use comes from renewable sources. We decided to pursue electrification of the fleet back in 2021 despite the unknowns and the supply challenges we could foresee. In Australia, only limited EVs that meet our needs are available on the market, so our planning had to start long ago.
column20: Energy Consumption, Office Space, Bank and Insurance

column13: We uplifted our capability to expand the measurement of GHG emissions for the Group across relevant Scope 3 categories. This activity will inform target setting across our operations and portfolios. The calculation of our Bank Scope 3 financed emissions based on absolute emissions (tCO2e) and emissions intensity (tCO2 e/$M) for all portfolios, with a specific breakdown of the business banking portfolio into ANZSIC Level 4 sector codes.
column20: Bank Lending, Bank Scope 3, Emissions Intensity

column13: We uplifted our capability to expand the measurement of GHG emissions for the Group across relevant Scope 3 categories. This activity will inform target setting across our operations and portfolios. Measuring our Scope 3 financed emissions associated with our investments portfolio for listed equities, Australian corporate bonds, sovereign and semi-government bonds, unlisted assets, global corporate bonds, convertible bonds, and other fixed-income securities.
column20: Investments, Scope 3 Financed Emissions, Investment Portfolio, Australian Corporate Bonds

column13: We uplifted our capability to expand the measurement of GHG emissions for the Group across relevant Scope 3 categories. This activity will inform target setting across our operations and portfolios. Measuring our Scope 3 financed emissions associated with our motor and commercial portfolios.

column13: We uplifted our capability to expand the measurement of GHG emissions for the Group across relevant Scope 3 categories. This activity will inform target setting across our operations and portfolios. Progressed our Scope 1 & 2 measurement and expanded our Scope 3 coverage by measuring and analysing material direct supply chain emissions hotspots (excluding claims supply chain) across all relevant upstream emissions categories as outlined in the GHG protocolÃ¢ÂÂs Corporate Value Chain (Scope 3) Standard.
column20: Controlled Operations, Measuring and Analysing Material, Direct Supply Chain

column13: Recognising there are varying levels of net-zero maturity within our supply chain, as part of the GroupÃ¢ÂÂs net-zero transition planning process, we will seek to engage with key suppliers to understand levels of maturity and areas where we can support. It will include data capture to improve the measurement and tracking of material emissions from selected suppliers. Future engagement targets are being considered within our net-zero transition planning process.
column20: Net-Zero Maturity, Net-Zero Transition Planning, Future Engagement

column13: The Bank commenced targeted engagement with several suppliers in FY23, including mail and transport, stationery, advertising and cash handling to improve the quality of source data capture further to refine the BankÃ¢ÂÂs controlled operations Scope 3 baseline and to explore zero maturity across material suppliers. This engagement also started valuable conversations with suppliers on net-zero transition planning and emissions reduction initiatives across the BankÃ¢ÂÂs supply chain.
column20: Mail and Transport, Bank's controlled operation, Bank's Supply Chain

column13: Suncorp commits to playing our part in reducing our climate impact.3 We have committed to developing pathways towards net zero across material areas of our controlled operations by 2030. We will also engage with our claims supply chain and explore an approach to transition our material-financed emissions to net zero. A transition plan is in development to detail our milestones and critical activities to achieve our emission reduction and engagement targets
column20: Net Zero, Material Areas, Claims Supply

column8: Home Claims | Supply Chain Environment Journey
column13: We are beginning to consider the environmental impacts within the home claims supply chain. As part of the journey to net zero, we will work with our key suppliers to understand emissions and then look at pathways to reduce environmental impact. Our recently developed Restoration Strategy aims to improve customer and business outcomes and, importantly, starts the journey, in partnership with our suppliers, to understand and reduce the environmental impacts.
column20: Home Claims, Environmental Impact, Partnership with Supplier

column13: Our Motor Claims team works alongside the Insurance Council of Australia (ICA) and our peers to support the industryÃ¢ÂÂs Climate Change Roadmap and net-zero working group in a motor claims decarbonisation pilot. The pilot aims to develop a process to identify high-emissions suppliers and opportunities to obtain better data to enable more accurate accounting for GHG emissions within the sector.
column20: Motor Claims, Insurance Council of Australia (ICA), Climate Change Roadmap

column13: In July 2022, Climate Active certified Suncorp Bank as a Carbon Neutral organisation (Certified Organisation) with Carbon Neutral personal transaction deposit services (Certified Service). Climate Active is the Australian national certifier of carbon neutrality that maintains and enforces the Carbon Neutral Standards, which provide a transparent methodology for determining operational emissions.
column20: Carbon Neutral Bank, Certified Organisation, Carbon Neutral Standards

column13: SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs insurance business in Australia and New Zealand is positioned across the essential motor, home, commercial, personal injury and compulsory third-party (CTP) portfolios. As one of the largest trans-Tasman insurers, we are responding to a shifting climate through resilience initiatives, building capability to enhance our event response and responding to market shifts to electric vehicles. We will draw on insights from this yearÃ¢ÂÂs Climate Change Scenario Analysis (CCSA) and embed them into strategy and business planning.
column20: Compulsory Third Party (CTP), Resilience Initiatives, Climate Change Scenario Analysis

column13: Over recent years, we have significantly enhanced our pricing capability and risk selection by embedding our Customer and Pricing Ecosystem (CaPE) system across our Australian home and commercial portfolios. It allows us to price for natural peril risk more effectively and accurately. It allows us to apply increases in premiums directly associated with the risk level not just by geography but at a specific individual risk address. We have also increased our resilience by resetting our natural hazard allowance.
column20: Customer and Pricing Ecosystem, Australian Home, Premiums

column13: Our Disaster Response team have adopted data and intelligence to enhance our ability to support our customers as natural hazard events change in frequency and severity in a warming climate. We use meteorological data and aerial imagery that captures regional, suburb, street and property level images combined with satellite analytics overlayed with our risk profile. It helps us to understand potential exposure to impending events so we can help customers to prepare better.
column20: Disaster Response team, Data and Intelligence, Artificial Intelligence

column13: Building on the success of the Solar Home Bonus campaign in FY22, we launched a Green Upgrades Equity Home Loan, which offers home lending customers access to low-rate finance to support finance for energy and water efficiency upgrades to homes.
column20: Solar Home Bonus Campaign, Green Upgrades Equity Home Loan, Low-Rate Finance

column13: Suncorp Bank also launched the Carbon Insights Account, AustraliaÃ¢ÂÂs first Climate Active certified carbon neutral personal transaction deposit account, allowing customers to view an estimate of emissions for their purchases powered by carbon accounting fintech, Cogo. The account helps to raise customer awareness of their own emissions footprint.
column20: Carbon Insights Account, Climate Active Certified Carbon Neutral, Emissions Footprint

column13: This year, we leveraged geospatial capability and improved our analysis from top-down postcode level assessment to bottom-up property level analysis. We analysed physical risk only across our commercial and residential assets and both physical and transition risk as part of a limited pilot on drought peril only for Agribusiness.
column20: Top-Down Postcode, Level Assessment, Property Level Analysis

column13: Suncorp also employs the mechanism of a shadow carbon price to manage the risk of assets becoming stranded due to the transition to a low-carbon economy. Our investment managers apply the shadow carbon price to analyse potential investments. They must avoid companies whose value would be materially impaired by using the shadow carbon price.
column20: Shadow Carbon Price, Risk of Assets, Low Carbon Economy

column13: Suncorp is committed to phasing out underwriting and direct investment in thermal coal by 2025. It includes mining companies principally involved in the extraction of thermal coal and electricity generation companies whose business is inconsistent with the transition to a net-zero emissions economy by 2050. It is defined as more than 10 per cent of the companyÃ¢ÂÂs revenue derived from thermal coal extraction or electricity generation.
column20: Thermal Coal, Mining Companies, Electricity Generation Companies

column13: SuncorpÃ¢ÂÂs goal of supporting the transition to a decarbonised economy is captured, in part, through our commitment to phase out investment exposure to oil and gas exploration and production by 2040. To achieve this, the Group committed, from 1 July 2020, to immediately exclude from its investment portfolio the top 10 per cent of oil and gas emitters, increasing this to 25 per cent by 2025 and 50 per cent by 2030, by kg CO2 per barrel of oil equivalent (BOE). Due to data availability constraints, we have updated the Standard to align our methodology with those more frequently used by financial organisations and asset managers. The Standard was revised in FY23 to apply a metric tonne of CO2 -equivalent /million of USD revenue, based on Scope 1 & 2 emissions rather than a BOE metric.
column20: Decarbonised Economy, Oil & Gas Exploration, Standards

column13: To support the transition to a decarbonised economy, the Standard includes an exemption enabling underwriting and investing in companies whose business is consistent with the transition to a net-zero carbon emissions economy by 2050. A credible transition plan assessment framework that defines and assesses the credibility of a companyÃ¢ÂÂs transition pathway is currently in development to support the business before this exemption is used
column20: Decarbonised Economy, Credible Transition Plan Assessment Framework, Business

column13: This year, we undertook a TCFD gap analysis and maturity assessment and began to take action on critical recommendations within this 2022-23 Climate-related Disclosure Report. The Group also launched a gap analysis on IFRSÃ¢ÂÂ ISSB Standard 2 guidelines in preparation for the Australian GovernmentÃ¢ÂÂs regulatory decision on mandatory climate disclosures.
column20: TCFD Gap Analysis, Clumate-Relate Disclosure Report, IFRS'ISSB
